Both of you pose fair points, but why not just meet somewhere in the middle?  Maybe take the dark designs and lace in some of the blue Shen currently wears in spots that'd tone down the sinister look while still being awesome and ninja-like.  Not all blue, of course, but not all black/gray/zed either.  A balance. :D

It really is that simple. Just lace it with some blue or lighten it to a dark blue (which would be more practical, anyway; a solid mass of black is easier to spot on a starry or moonlit night than something that would match the night sky), and it would address both sides.

This rule also applies to Maokai, he's actually a good guy too! Looks like a terrifying monster tree, is trying to save the world from the Shadow Isles. If anything being dark and sinister looking while being a good guy is a cool foil; it makes for some really interesting characters imo.

Here's the main problem: How do you make a character look like a ninja and a tank at the same time? Tanky champions are usually big and bulky to signify that they can take punishment, but a ninja is quick and agile and doesn't want to be weighed down with a lot of armor. They contradict each other; Unless you want to make a dodge tank, which probably wouldn't be healthy for the game.

I remember one of the Rioters on the art team talking about how Shen wouldn't have been made today. He said (paraphrasing) that marrying the concepts of a "tank" and "ninja" would be problematic. I assume that same reason is why Shen hasn't gotten a visual update, they have no idea how to do it.

> [{quoted}](name=BastionKross,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=2VPffRyK,comment-id=0008,timestamp=2015-03-21T15:08:17.789+0000)
>
> Here's the main problem: How do you make a character look like a ninja and a tank at the same time?

Well you start by creating something new that isn't already a trope or stereotype.

It's perfectly reasonable to assume that someone can be "tanky" through magical or supernatural means. Shen could be given a very conservative ninja outfit with a ghostly armor around him, signifying that he is under supernatural protection.

(Technically, though, the stereotypical ninja outfit is wrong. it's the outfits used by stage actors who are meant to be seen as invisible while they move around the background scenery in a play. There were plays in which characters were supposed to be assassinated by surprise, and the playwright chose to have this done by one of those background characters, which led to the trope - Ninjas in real life were indistinguishable from average ordinary people)

Shen, being the noble protector that he is, would choose to protect his friends with his ghostly armor, even if it put himself in danger. 

That right there is just a half-assed attempt to explain his mechanics and his look. It seems like it would work just fine.
